title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
A survey, Indirect Assessment in Quantitative Reasoning, was used to complement the Quantitative Reasoning Rubric for direct assessment.



The survey was distributed through Google Forms to assess quantitative reasoning skills and engagement using the ‚ÄúStandard Form.‚Äù
The data was collected during the last two weeks of the Spring 2024 semester, resulting in 469 complete student responses.



Variable names, full wording of the questions, short labels used in analyses, and the response sets are as follows.


Variable Name[Short label] Full Wording of the Question and the Response Setq1_methodology[Methodology] Throughout this course, how often have you done each of the following?... Describe the methods that you chose to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q2_calculation[Calculation]... Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q3_visual_representation[Visual Representation]... Created a visual representation of numerical information, such as a graph, table, chart, or diagram.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q4_interpretation[Interpretation]... Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q5_evaluation[Evaluation]... Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q6_coherence_purpose[Coherence/Purpose]... Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q7_reasonableness[Reasonableness]... Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q8_used_qr[QR in World Issues]... Used quantitative reasoning to examine a real-world problem or issue (unemployment, climate change, public health, etc.)    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q9_improve_general[Improved General QR] Describe how much this course has improved your general quantitative/numerical skills.    None (1) / Minor improvement (2) / Moderate improvement (3) / Major improvement (4)q10_improve_realworld[Improved Applied QR] Describe how much this course has improved your ability to apply your quantitative/numerical skills to real-world problems.    None (1) / Minor improvement (2) / Moderate improvement (3) / Major improvement (4)q11_confidence[Confidence] Describe how confident you feel using numbers in your everyday life.    None (1) / Minor improvement (2) / Moderate improvement (3) / Major improvement (4)q12_example_qr_class[Example class] Please give an example of a quantitative skill that you developed in this course that you feel will be important in the future (such as in a future class, workplace, or daily life).    Open-ended questionq13_freq_calculations[Frequency of Calculations] How frequently do you do calculations in your everyday life?    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q14_freq_graphs_tables[Frequency of Graph Use] How frequently do you encounter graphs and tables in your everyday life?    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q15_freq_course_situations[Frequency of Encounters] How frequently in your daily life do you encounter situations like those you have learned about in this course?    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q16_example_qr_life[Example life] Please give an example of a time when you used "quantitative reasoning" in your daily life.    Open-ended question

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text: A survey, Indirect Assessment in Quantitative Reasoning, was used to complement the Quantitative Reasoning Rubric for direct assessment.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
The survey was distributed through Google Forms to assess quantitative reasoning skills and engagement using the ‚ÄúStandard Form.‚Äù
The data was collected during the last two weeks of the Spring 2024 semester, resulting in 469 complete student responses.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
2.1 Quantitative Reasoning Skills: Summary

2.1.1 Table 1. Frequencies of Core Quantitative Reasoning Skills


Core QR Skills - ItemsN = 4691[Methodology] Described the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate    Never19 (4.1%)    Infrequently57 (12%)    Sometimes202 (43%)    Frequently188 (40%)[Calculation] Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software    Never9 (1.9%)    Infrequently30 (6.4%)    Sometimes125 (27%)    Frequently304 (65%)[Visual Representation] Created a visual representation of numerical information (graph, table, chart, etc.)    Never14 (3.0%)    Infrequently33 (7.0%)    Sometimes157 (33%)    Frequently265 (57%)[Interpretation] Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words    Never12 (2.6%)    Infrequently51 (11%)    Sometimes151 (32%)    Frequently252 (54%)[Evaluation] Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)    Never10 (2.1%)    Infrequently42 (9.0%)    Sometimes175 (38%)    Frequently239 (51%)[Coherence/Purpose] Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence    Never27 (5.8%)    Infrequently89 (19%)    Sometimes190 (41%)    Frequently159 (34%)[Reasonableness] Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem    Never17 (3.6%)    Infrequently53 (11%)    Sometimes219 (47%)    Frequently179 (38%)1n (%)


Table 1 presents the frequencies of student engagement in various quantitative activities within the class, measured through seven different questions.
‚ÄúCarried out calculations, either by hand or using software,‚Äù shows that a significant majority of students, 65%, frequently engage in calculations. ‚ÄúCreated a visual representation, like a graph, chart, or diagram,‚Äù indicates that 56.5% of students frequently create visual representations. ‚ÄúInterpreted numerical information by writing in words,‚Äù shows 54.1% of students frequently interpret numerical data in written form.
The last three items received the least ‚Äúfrequently‚Äù responses display more advanced quantitative reasoning and analysis.‚ÄùDescribed the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate‚Äù shows 40.3% of students frequently describe methodology. ‚ÄúDecided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem‚Äù indicates that 38.2% of students frequently assess reasonableness. Finally, the item ‚ÄúConstructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence‚Äù has the lowest ‚Äúfrequently‚Äù response at 34.2%, which is less common among students.


2.1.2 Figure 1. Frequencies of Core Quantitative Reasoning Skills





Note 1: Alternative of the above table.Note 2: The items are sorted by the responses that received the most ‚Äòfrequently‚Äô responses.






2.1.3 Table 2. Descriptive Statistics of Core Quantitative Reasoning Skills


Core QR Skills - ItemsN = 4691[Calculation] Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software3.55 (0.70)[Visual Representation] Created a visual representation of numerical information (graph, table, chart, etc.)3.43 (0.75)[Interpretation] Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words3.38 (0.78)[Evaluation] Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)3.38 (0.74)[Methodology] Described the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate3.20 (0.81)[Reasonableness] Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem3.20 (0.78)[Coherence/Purpose] Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence3.03 (0.88)1Mean (SD)


Table 2 presents the descriptive statistics of core quantitative reasoning skills. The highest mean score is for ‚ÄúCalculation‚Äù at 3.55 out of four. ‚ÄúVisual representation‚Äù has a mean score of 3.43. ‚ÄúInterpretation‚Äù and ‚ÄúEvaluation‚Äù both have a mean score of 3.38. Students describe numerical information in written form and reach conclusions based on analysis at similar frequencies.
‚ÄúReasonableness‚Äù and ‚ÄúMethodology‚Äù both score 3.20. Students decide when solutions are reasonable in context and describe methods used to solve quantitative problems at moderate frequencies. ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose,‚Äù which involves constructing coherent arguments using multiple quantitative conclusions, has a mean score of 3.03. Students construct coherent arguments using several conclusions based on quantitative evidence less frequently than other skills.
The standard deviations range from 0.70 to 0.88, with ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù showing the highest variability among students (SD = 0.88). In contrast, ‚ÄúCalculation‚Äù (SD = 0.70) and ‚ÄúVisual Representation‚Äù (SD = 0.75) show more consistent performance across students.


2.1.4 Figure 2. Descriptive Statistics of Quantitative Reasoning Skills





Note: Alternative of the above table.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
section: 2.2 Quantitative Reasoning Improvement and Confidence: Summary
text:
2.2 Quantitative Reasoning Improvement and Confidence: Summary

2.2.1 Table 3. Frequencies of Quantitative Reasoning Improvement and Confidence


QR Improvement and Confidence - ItemsN = 4691[Improved General QR] How much has this course improved your general quantitative/numerical skills?    None32 (6.8%)    Minor improvement42 (9.0%)    Moderate improvement266 (57%)    Major improvement128 (27%)[Improved Applied QR] How much has this course improved your ability to apply QR to real-world problems?    None16 (3.4%)    Minor improvement92 (20%)    Moderate improvement208 (44%)    Major improvement153 (33%)[Confidence] How confident do you feel using numbers in your everyday life?    Not at all confident12 (2.6%)    Not confident27 (5.8%)    Confident280 (60%)    Very confident147 (32%)1n (%)


Table 3 presents the frequencies of student responses regarding course improvement and confidence in quantitative reasoning.
For general quantitative/numerical skills improvement, most students (57%) report moderate improvement, with 27% reporting major improvement. Only 6.8% of students indicate no improvement in their quantitative skills from the course.
Similarly, for applied QR skills improvement, 56% of students report moderate improvement and 27% report major improvement in their ability to apply quantitative reasoning to real-world problems. A small percentage (8.5%) report no improvement in this area.
Regarding confidence in using numbers in everyday life, the majority of students feel confident (60%) or very confident (32%). Only 2.6% of students report feeling not at all confident, with 5.8% feeling not confident in using numbers day-to-day.


2.2.2 Figure 3. Frequencies of Quantitative Reasoning Improvement and Confidence





Note 1: Alternative of the above table.Note 2: Different response scales are used: QR Improvement (1‚Äì4: None to Major improvement) and Confidence (1‚Äì4: Not at all confident to Very confident).






2.2.3 Table 4. Descriptive Statistics of Quantitative Reasoning Improvement and Confidence


QR Improvement and Confidence - ItemsN = 4691[Confidence] How confident do you feel using numbers in your everyday life?3.21 (0.66)[Improved Applied QR] How much has this course improved your ability to apply QR to real-world problems?3.06 (0.81)[Improved General QR] How much has this course improved your general quantitative/numerical skills?3.05 (0.80)1Mean (SD)


Table 4 presents the descriptive statistics of student improvement and confidence measures. Students report high confidence in using numbers in everyday life (M = 3.21). This score is the highest among the three measures.
Applied quantitative skill improvement shows a mean of 3.06. Students report similar levels of improvement in applying quantitative reasoning to real-world problems, with a mean of 3.05.


2.2.4 Figure 4. Descriptive Statistics of Quantitative Reasoning Improvement and Confidence





Note 1: Alternative of the above table.Note 2: Different response scales are used: QR Improvement (1-4: None to Major improvement) and Confidence (1-4: Not at all confident to Very confident).

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
2.3 Quantitative Reasoning Engagement: Summary

2.3.1 Table 5. Frequencies of Quantitative Reasoning Engagement


Frequency of QR Engagement - ItemsN = 4691[QR in World Issues] Used quantitative reasoning to examine a real-world problem or issue    Never39 (8.3%)    Infrequently78 (17%)    Sometimes178 (38%)    Frequently174 (37%)[Frequency of Calculations] How frequently do you do calculations in your everyday life?    Never33 (7.1%)    Infrequently109 (23%)    Sometimes197 (42%)    Frequently127 (27%)[Frequency of Graph Use] How frequently do you encounter graphs and tables in your everyday life?    Never78 (17%)    Infrequently179 (38%)    Sometimes141 (30%)    Frequently70 (15%)[Frequency of Encounters] How frequently in your daily life do you encounter situations like those you have learned about in this course?    Never80 (17%)    Infrequently180 (38%)    Sometimes158 (34%)    Frequently51 (11%)1n (%)


Table 5 presents the frequencies of student engagement with quantitative reasoning in various contexts.
For using quantitative reasoning to examine world issues, 37% of students do this frequently. For calculations in everyday life, 27% of students perform these frequently. Graph and table usage shows 15% of students encounter these frequently. Regarding course-related situations in daily life, 11% of students encounter these frequently.
These results show that quantitative reasoning skills are most frequently applied when examining world issues, followed by performing everyday calculations.


2.3.2 Figure 5. Frequencies of Quantitative Reasoning Engagement





Note: Alternative of the above table.






2.3.3 Table 6. Descriptive Statistics of Quantitative Reasoning Engagement


Frequency of QR Engagement - ItemsN = 4691[QR in World Issues] Used quantitative reasoning to examine a real-world problem or issue3.04 (0.93)[Frequency of Calculations] How frequently do you do calculations in your everyday life?2.90 (0.88)[Frequency of Graph Use] How frequently do you encounter graphs and tables in your everyday life?2.43 (0.94)[Frequency of Encounters] How frequently in your daily life do you encounter situations like those you have learned about in this course?2.38 (0.89)1Mean (SD)


Table 6 presents the descriptive statistics of quantitative reasoning engagement measures.
Students most frequently use quantitative reasoning to examine world issues (M = 3.04). Frequency of calculations in everyday life shows a mean of 2.90. Graph and table usage displays a mean of 2.43.
Frequency of encountering course-related situations in daily life has the lowest mean at 2.38. Students experience situations similar to those taught in the course less frequently than other forms of quantitative engagement.


2.3.4 Figure 6. Descriptive Statistics of Quantitative Reasoning Engagement





Note: Alternative of the above table.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
section: 3.1 Figure 9. Correlation Matrix of All Variables
text:
3.1 Figure 9. Correlation Matrix of All Variables





Note: Bottom-left cells show scatterplots; diagonal cells show variable distributions. Top-right values are Pearson r coefficients. Correlation strength: weak (|r| < 0.3), moderate (0.3 < |r| < 0.5), strong (|r| > 0.5). * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001.




Figure 9 presents the correlation matrix of all variables.
The strongest correlations within the core quantitative reasoning skills are observed between:

Coherence/Purpose and Reasonableness (r = 0.68, p<0.001)
Evaluation and Interpretation (r = 0.64, p<0.001)
Interpretation and Visual Representation (r = 0.61, p<0.001)

These strong correlations may suggest that students who build coherent arguments backed by quantitative evidence also tend to judge the reasonableness of solutions. Students with strong evaluation skills typically have strong interpretation abilities, and those who interpret numerical information also create visual representations of data.
The correlation between ‚ÄúHow much has this course improved your general quantitative/numerical skills?‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow much has this course improved your ability to apply QR to real-world problems?‚Äù (r = 0.90, p<0.001). Notably, ‚ÄúConfidence in using numbers‚Äù shows no significant correlations with any variables, which may suggest that confidence operates somewhat independently from the reported quantitative reasoning skills, improvement, and engagement.
The ‚ÄúUsing quantitative reasoning to examine real-world problems‚Äù shows moderate correlations with core quantitative reasoning skills, particularly with Methodology (r = 0.55, p<0.001) and Reasonableness (r = 0.51, p<0.001). This suggests relationships between classroom-based skills and their application to real-world issues.
Within the qualitative reasoning engagement variables, the analysis reveals a statistically significant correlation (r = 0.68, p<0.001) between students‚Äô reported frequency of encountering graphs and tables in everyday life and their experience with course-related situations in daily contexts.
The weakest correlations involve ‚ÄúUsed quantitative reasoning to examine a real-world problem or issue,‚Äù which shows moderate correlations with ‚ÄúHow frequently do you do calculations in your everyday life?‚Äù (r = 0.24, p<0.001), ‚ÄúHow frequently do you encounter graphs and tables in your everyday life?‚Äù (r= 0.26, p<0.001), and ‚ÄúHow frequently in your daily life do you encounter situations like those you have learned about in this course?‚Äù (r = 0.34, p<0.001).

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
3.2 Figure 10. Correlogram of All Variables





Note 1: Alternative of the above graph.Note 2: Cells represent the correlation coefficient between two variables. Blue shows positive correlations, red shows negative correlations, and circle size reflects correlation magnitude. Correlation strength: weak (|r| < 0.3), moderate (0.3 < |r| < 0.5), strong (|r| > 0.5). Insignificant correlations are invisible (p > .05).

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
section: 4.1 Table 9. Linear Regression Model Predicting Coherence/Purpose
text:
4.1 Table 9. Linear Regression Model Predicting Coherence/Purpose


Linear Regression Model Predicting Coherence/PurposePredictorEstimateSE95% CIp-valueIntercept-0.01(0.03)[-0.06, 0.05]0.837Methodology0.21***(0.05)[0.11, 0.30]0.000Calculation-0.11‚Ä†(0.06)[-0.22, 0.00]0.053Visual Representation-0.05(0.05)[-0.16, 0.05]0.310Interpretation0.07(0.06)[-0.04, 0.18]0.209Evaluation0.24***(0.06)[0.13, 0.35]0.000Reasonableness0.53***(0.05)[0.43, 0.63]0.000SE = Standard Error, CI = Confidence Interval‚Ä† p < .10, * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001R¬≤ = 0.511; Adjusted R¬≤ = 0.505


A linear regression was conducted to identify the factors that influence students‚Äô ability to construct a single, coherent argument using several conclusions based on quantitative evidence‚Äîreferred to as ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose.‚Äù This item received the lowest ‚Äúfrequently‚Äù responses at 34.2%, as noted in prior sections. Note that all variables were mean-centered prior to analyses to minimize multicollinearity.
The results reveal that four skills significantly influence the ability to construct coherent quantitative arguments. Specifically, the skill of describing the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and justifying their appropriateness increases the ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù score by 0.21 points on a 1-to-4 scale. Similarly, the ability to reach conclusions based on one‚Äôs own analysis of numerical information, such as numbers, graphs, or statistics, increases the score by 0.24 points. The most substantial impact arises from deciding when a solution or inference is reasonable within a problem‚Äôs context, which increases the Coherence/Purpose score by 0.53 points. Finally, ‚ÄúCarried out calculations, either by hand or using software‚Äù shows a negative effect, decreasing the Coherence/Purpose score by 0.11 points. This effect is significant at a marginal level (p < 0.10), a less reliable but noteworthy influence that warrants further exploration. The model explains approximately 51.1% of the variance in ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù (R¬≤ = 0.511).

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
section: 4.2 Table 11. Linear Regression Model Predicting Core Quantitative Reasoning Improvement
text:
4.2 Table 11. Linear Regression Model Predicting Core Quantitative Reasoning Improvement


Linear Regression Model Predicting QR ImprovementPredictorEstimateSE95% CIp-valueIntercept0.01(0.03)[-0.04, 0.06]0.717QR Core Skills0.55***(0.05)[0.46, 0.65]0.000Confidence-0.03(0.04)[-0.10, 0.05]0.467QR Engagement0.29***(0.04)[0.21, 0.37]0.000SE = Standard Error, CI = Confidence Interval‚Ä† p < .10, * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001R¬≤ = 0.430; Adjusted R¬≤ = 0.426


A linear regression was conducted to identify the factors that influence students‚Äô self-reported improvement. For this analysis, composite indexes were used.
The results reveal that quantitative reasoning core skills increases the improvement score by 0.55 points on a 1-to-4 scale. Similarly, qualitative reasoning engagement increases the score by 0.29 points. However, confidence has no effect on the improvement score. The model explains approximately 43% of the variance in ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù (R¬≤ = 0.430).

title: Step 3: Download/upload data and other files to RStudio
text:
Download the data file

After the data collection process is completed, your data is ready to upload.
Go to the ‚ÄúResponses‚Äù tab of the Google Form.
Click the three dots (next to ‚ÄúLink to Sheets‚Äù) ‚ûú ‚ÄúDownload responses (.csv)‚Äù

The file will be downloaded as a .zip folder.
Double-click that folder to extract the file.
Rename the file name to ‚Äúdf.csv‚Äù (Make sure it‚Äôs not ‚Äúdf.csv.csv‚Äù).




Download the Quarto file
Click to download the Quarto file:

Short form Quarto file

OR

Standard form Quarto file



Download the Word Template file
Click to download the Word Template file:
QR_Report_Template.docx


Upload these files to RStudio

Upload these three files (df.csv, .qmd, and the Word Template files) to RStudio one by one.



You will see three files under the ‚ÄúFiles‚Äù tab.
Click on ‚Äústandard.qmd‚Äù or ‚Äúshort.qmd‚Äù (the version you use):



Clicking on the .qmd file will open it on RStudio.
Click ‚ÄúRun‚Äù ‚ûú ‚ÄúRun All.



This process will install all the packages. For the first time the codes are run, this process may take 15-20 minutes or shorter depending on your internet connection.
You will see a STOP sign and codes are running in the console. You should wait until the ‚ÄúSTOP‚Äù sign in the console disappears and no more code is running in the console.



During this process, if you see the pop-up window above (Updating Loaded Packages), click ‚ÄúNo‚Äù every single time.
crumbs: Step 3: Download/upload data and other files to RStudio

title: Step 1: Collect data
text:
Short form (7 questions)
This survey directly aligns with CSUMB‚Äôs seven QR areas and enables:

Reporting of both direct assessment scores (student proficiency) and indirect survey results (frequency of skill practice);
Comprehensive insight into students‚Äô QR experiences.

Short Form: Make a copy of the survey


Standard Form (16 questions)
The inclusion of the additional questions in this survey is ideal for:
1.¬† Evaluating QR skills across different content areas or ULOs;
2.¬† Exploring how students use QR skills in practical contexts.
Standard Form: Make a copy of the survey

title: Step 4: Organize the content and render
text:
Render the content and download the Word document

Click the arrow next to the ‚ÄúRender‚Äù ‚ûú ‚ÄúRender MS Word.‚Äù



Click ‚ÄúDownload file.‚Äù

Delete any tables/figures you don‚Äôt want to use, and revise the interpretations accordingly.
Render the content in HTML
Alternatively, you could create an HTML document by making changes in the .qmd file.

Click ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù ‚ûú ‚ÄúPreview in Viewer Pane.‚Äù





Make changes in the .qmd file, such as deleting unwanted tables/graphs and adding your interpretations.
Click the arrow next to the ‚ÄúRender‚Äù ‚ûú ‚ÄúRender HTML.‚Äù

You will see the content under the ‚ÄúViewer‚Äù tab. If you want to view the HTML report in your browser, click ‚ÄúShow in new window.‚Äù
crumbs: Step 4: Organize the content and render

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
A survey, Indirect Assessment in Quantitative Reasoning, was used to complement the Quantitative Reasoning Rubric for direct assessment.



The survey was distributed through Google Forms to assess quantitative reasoning skills and engagement using the ‚ÄúShort Form.‚Äù
The data was collected during the last two weeks of the Spring 2024 semester, resulting in 469 complete student responses.



Variable names, full wording of the questions, short labels used in analyses, and the response sets are as follows.


Variable Name[Short label] Full Wording of the Question and the Response Setq1_methodology[Methodology] Throughout this course, how often have you done each of the following?... Describe the methods that you chose to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q2_calculation[Calculation]... Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q3_visual_representation[Visual Representation]... Created a visual representation of numerical information, such as a graph, table, chart, or diagram.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q4_interpretation[Interpretation]... Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q5_evaluation[Evaluation]... Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q6_coherence_purpose[Coherence/Purpose]... Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q7_reasonableness[Reasonableness]... Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text: A survey, Indirect Assessment in Quantitative Reasoning, was used to complement the Quantitative Reasoning Rubric for direct assessment.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
The survey was distributed through Google Forms to assess quantitative reasoning skills and engagement using the ‚ÄúShort Form.‚Äù
The data was collected during the last two weeks of the Spring 2024 semester, resulting in 469 complete student responses.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
Variable names, full wording of the questions, short labels used in analyses, and the response sets are as follows.


Variable Name[Short label] Full Wording of the Question and the Response Setq1_methodology[Methodology] Throughout this course, how often have you done each of the following?... Describe the methods that you chose to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q2_calculation[Calculation]... Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q3_visual_representation[Visual Representation]... Created a visual representation of numerical information, such as a graph, table, chart, or diagram.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q4_interpretation[Interpretation]... Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q5_evaluation[Evaluation]... Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q6_coherence_purpose[Coherence/Purpose]... Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence.    Never (1) / Infrequently (2) / Sometimes (3) / Frequently (4)q7_reasonableness[Reasonableness]... Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
2.1 Quantitative Reasoning Skills: Summary

2.1.1 Table 1. Frequencies of Core Quantitative Reasoning Skills


Core QR Skills - ItemsN = 4691[Methodology] Described the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate    Never19 (4.1%)    Infrequently57 (12%)    Sometimes202 (43%)    Frequently188 (40%)[Calculation] Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software    Never9 (1.9%)    Infrequently30 (6.4%)    Sometimes125 (27%)    Frequently304 (65%)[Visual Representation] Created a visual representation of numerical information (graph, table, chart, etc.)    Never14 (3.0%)    Infrequently33 (7.0%)    Sometimes157 (33%)    Frequently265 (57%)[Interpretation] Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words    Never12 (2.6%)    Infrequently51 (11%)    Sometimes151 (32%)    Frequently252 (54%)[Evaluation] Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)    Never10 (2.1%)    Infrequently42 (9.0%)    Sometimes175 (38%)    Frequently239 (51%)[Coherence/Purpose] Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence    Never27 (5.8%)    Infrequently89 (19%)    Sometimes190 (41%)    Frequently159 (34%)[Reasonableness] Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem    Never17 (3.6%)    Infrequently53 (11%)    Sometimes219 (47%)    Frequently179 (38%)1n (%)


Table 1 presents the frequencies of student engagement in various quantitative activities within the class, measured through seven different questions.
‚ÄúCarried out calculations, either by hand or using software,‚Äù shows that a significant majority of students, 65%, frequently engage in calculations. ‚ÄúCreated a visual representation, like a graph, chart, or diagram,‚Äù indicates that 56.5% of students frequently create visual representations. ‚ÄúInterpreted numerical information by writing in words,‚Äù shows 54.1% of students frequently interpret numerical data in written form.
The last three items received the least ‚Äúfrequently‚Äù responses display more advanced quantitative reasoning and analysis.‚ÄùDescribed the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate‚Äù shows 40.3% of students frequently describe methodology. ‚ÄúDecided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem‚Äù indicates that 38.2% of students frequently assess reasonableness. Finally, the item ‚ÄúConstructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence‚Äù has the lowest ‚Äúfrequently‚Äù response at 34.2%, which is less common among students.


2.1.2 Figure 1. Frequencies of Core Quantitative Reasoning Skills





Note 1: Alternative of the above table.Note 2: The items are sorted by the responses that received the most ‚Äòfrequently‚Äô responses.






2.1.3 Table 2. Descriptive Statistics of Core Quantitative Reasoning Skills


Core QR Skills - ItemsN = 4691[Calculation] Carried out calculations, either by hand or using software3.55 (0.70)[Visual Representation] Created a visual representation of numerical information (graph, table, chart, etc.)3.43 (0.75)[Interpretation] Described numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.) by writing in words3.38 (0.78)[Evaluation] Reached conclusions based on your own analysis of numerical information (numbers, graphs, statistics, etc.)3.38 (0.74)[Methodology] Described the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and why they were appropriate3.20 (0.81)[Reasonableness] Decided when a solution or inference was reasonable or not reasonable in the context of a problem3.20 (0.78)[Coherence/Purpose] Constructed a single, coherent argument using several conclusions that were each based on quantitative evidence3.03 (0.88)1Mean (SD)


Table 2 presents the descriptive statistics of core quantitative reasoning skills. The highest mean score is for ‚ÄúCalculation‚Äù at 3.55 out of four. ‚ÄúVisual representation‚Äù has a mean score of 3.43. ‚ÄúInterpretation‚Äù and ‚ÄúEvaluation‚Äù both have a mean score of 3.38. Students describe numerical information in written form and reach conclusions based on analysis at similar frequencies.
‚ÄúReasonableness‚Äù and ‚ÄúMethodology‚Äù both score 3.20. Students decide when solutions are reasonable in context and describe methods used to solve quantitative problems at moderate frequencies. ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose,‚Äù which involves constructing coherent arguments using multiple quantitative conclusions, has a mean score of 3.03. Students construct coherent arguments using several conclusions based on quantitative evidence less frequently than other skills.
The standard deviations range from 0.70 to 0.88, with ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù showing the highest variability among students (SD = 0.88). In contrast, ‚ÄúCalculation‚Äù (SD = 0.70) and ‚ÄúVisual Representation‚Äù (SD = 0.75) show more consistent performance across students.


2.1.4 Figure 2. Descriptive Statistics of Quantitative Reasoning Skills





Note: Alternative of the above table.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
section: 3.1 Figure 3. Correlation Matrix of All Variables
text:
3.1 Figure 3. Correlation Matrix of All Variables





Note: Bottom-left cells show scatterplots; diagonal cells show variable distributions. Top-right values are Pearson r coefficients. Correlation strength: weak (|r| < 0.3), moderate (0.3 < |r| < 0.5), strong (|r| > 0.5). * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001.




Figure 9 presents the correlation matrix of all variables.
The strongest correlations within the core quantitative reasoning skills are observed between:

Coherence/Purpose and Reasonableness (r = 0.68, p<0.001)
Evaluation and Interpretation (r = 0.64, p<0.001)
Interpretation and Visual Representation (r = 0.61, p<0.001)

These strong correlations may suggest that students who build coherent arguments backed by quantitative evidence also tend to judge the reasonableness of solutions. Students with strong evaluation skills typically have strong interpretation abilities, and those who interpret numerical information also create visual representations of data.

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
text:
3.2 Figure 4. Correlogram of All Variables





Note 1: Alternative of the above graph.Note 2: Cells represent the correlation coefficient between two variables. Blue shows positive correlations, red shows negative correlations, and circle size reflects correlation magnitude. Correlation strength: weak (|r| < 0.3), moderate (0.3 < |r| < 0.5), strong (|r| > 0.5). Insignificant correlations are invisible (p > .05).

title: Quantitative Reasoning Indirect Assessment Report
section: 4.1 Table 3. Linear Regression Model Predicting Coherence/Purpose
text:
4.1 Table 3. Linear Regression Model Predicting Coherence/Purpose


Linear Regression Model Predicting Coherence/PurposePredictorEstimateSE95% CIp-valueIntercept-0.01(0.03)[-0.06, 0.05]0.837Methodology0.21***(0.05)[0.11, 0.30]0.000Calculation-0.11‚Ä†(0.06)[-0.22, 0.00]0.053Visual Representation-0.05(0.05)[-0.16, 0.05]0.310Interpretation0.07(0.06)[-0.04, 0.18]0.209Evaluation0.24***(0.06)[0.13, 0.35]0.000Reasonableness0.53***(0.05)[0.43, 0.63]0.000SE = Standard Error, CI = Confidence Interval‚Ä† p < .10, * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001R¬≤ = 0.511; Adjusted R¬≤ = 0.505


A linear regression was conducted to identify the factors that influence students‚Äô ability to construct a single, coherent argument using several conclusions based on quantitative evidence‚Äîreferred to as ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose.‚Äù This item received the lowest ‚Äúfrequently‚Äù responses at 34.2%, as noted in prior sections. Note that all variables were mean-centered prior to analyses to minimize multicollinearity.
The results reveal that four skills significantly influence the ability to construct coherent quantitative arguments. Specifically, the skill of describing the methods used to solve a quantitative problem and justifying their appropriateness increases the ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù score by 0.21 points on a 1-to-4 scale. Similarly, the ability to reach conclusions based on one‚Äôs own analysis of numerical information, such as numbers, graphs, or statistics, increases the score by 0.24 points. The most substantial impact arises from deciding when a solution or inference is reasonable within a problem‚Äôs context, which increases the Coherence/Purpose score by 0.53 points. Finally, ‚ÄúCarried out calculations, either by hand or using software‚Äù shows a negative effect, decreasing the Coherence/Purpose score by 0.11 points. This effect is significant at a marginal level (p < 0.10), a less reliable but noteworthy influence that warrants further exploration. The model explains approximately 51.1% of the variance in ‚ÄúCoherence/Purpose‚Äù (R¬≤ = 0.511).

title: Step 2: Create an RStudio Cloud account
text:
The page will show how to create a RStudio Cloud account. You will be able to use this software on your browser.

Go to https://posit.cloud/plans/free (make sure you choose ‚Äúfree account‚Äù).
Click on ‚ÄúSign up.‚Äù
Put a password (at least 10 characters, with upper and lower case letters, a number, and a special character).
Type your first and last name.
When you click ‚ÄúSign up‚Äù you will receive an email for verification.
Go to your email inbox and click ‚ÄúVerify.‚Äù
You will be directed to Go to https://posit.cloud. If not, click on the link.
Click on ‚ÄúNew project‚Äù ‚ûú ‚ÄúNew RStudio Project.‚Äù
Wait for a minute or so until you see the screen below.
Click on ‚ÄúUntitled Project‚Äù (see highlighted part # 1) and type ‚ÄúIndirect Assessment in QR.‚Äù
crumbs: Step 2: Create an RStudio Cloud account

title: Word format
text: üìÑ Download the Word Version (Short)

title: Home
text:
Home
This site provides guidance on a survey tool to indirectly assess Quantitative Reasoning.
There are four steps:

Collect data
Create an RStudio Cloud account
Download/upload data and other files to RStudio
Organize the content and render

After completing these steps, RStudio (Quarto) will generate the report in both HTML and Word formats.
